April 20, 1997: Fiction
THE PARTNER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) The pursuit of $90 million
stolen by a Mississippi lawyer who has apparently died and been cremated -- but
is actually hiding in Brazil.
THE RANCH, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $25.95.) Three women who were
college roommates come to terms with themselves at a Wyoming resort.
CHROMOSOME 6, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $24.95.) The missing liver of a
corpse found floating in a river may provide clues to the murder of a crime figure.
3001: THE FINAL ODYSSEY, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.) One
of the heroes of ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' returns to life and tries to save the
human race from a dangerous monolith.
THE NOTEBOOK, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $16.95.) A World War II veteran
meets an old flame who is about to be married.
SANCTUARY, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $23.95.) A photographer, seeking to
come to grips with her past, returns to the Georgia inn that her family operates.
SMALL VICES, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $21.95.) The private eye Spenser
has a brush with death while pursuing a young woman's murderer.
MCNALLY'S GAMBLE, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $24.95.) Archy McNally,
hired by a rich widow's children, finds himself in a sea of greed and murder.
ACTS OF LOVE, by Judith Michael. (Crown, $24.) The discovery of a box of old
letters causes a man and a woman to seek a life together in the theater.
A THIN DARK LINE, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $22.95.) A Louisiana deputy's
determination to correct a botched murder case carries her into a morass of
treachery.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
EVENING CLASS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Family secrets,
aspirations and passions surface during a course in Italian at a Dublin school.
SOLE SURVIVOR, by Dean Koontz. (Knopf, $25.95.) A reporter searches for a
woman who claims to know a secret about the plane crash that killed his family.
TOTAL CONTROL, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $25.) A woman's effort to find her
husband, who has disappeared, reveals the ways of big business.
PLANET OF TWILIGHT, by Barbara Hambly. (Spectra/Bantam, $22.95.) The ''Star
Wars'' battle between the New Republic and the Empire takes a new turn.
April 20, 1997
Non-Fiction
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer
recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
PERSONAL HISTORY, by Katharine Graham. (Knopf, $29.95.) The
autobiography of the former publisher of The Washington Post and capital grande
dame.
MURDER IN BRENTWOOD, by Mark Fuhrman. (Regnery, $24.95.) The O. J.
Simpson murder trial as observed by the man who was a key prosecution witness.
THE GIFT OF PEACE, by Joseph Cardinal Bernardin. (Loyola Press, $17.95.)
Reflections on the last three years of his life by the late Archbishop of Chicago.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam, $19.95.) The
author addresses questions of life and love, good and evil, guilt and sin.
NAKED, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) Autobiographical comic essays.
THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko.
(Longstreet, $22.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans.
THE KISS, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $20.) A novelist recalls her love
affair with her father.
NICKEL DREAMS, by Tanya Tucker with Patsi Bale Cox. (Hyperion, $23.95.)
From Willcox, Ariz., to Nashville: the autobiography of the country singer.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
A REPORTER'S LIFE, by Walter Cronkite. (Knopf, $26.95.) The television
anchorman's memoirs.
DR. SUSAN LOVE'S HORMONE BOOK, by Susan M. Love with Karen Lindsey.
(Random House, $25.) A physician discusses the problems attending menopause.
FLYING BLIND, FLYING SAFE, by Mary Schiavo with Sabra Chartrand. (Avon,
$25.) The former Inspector General of the Department of Transportation describes
the perils that await airline passengers.
MY SERGEI, by Ekaterina Gordeeva with E. M. Swift. (Warner, $18.95.) A memoir
of the Russian ice skater Sergei Grinkov by his longtime partner and wife.
JOURNEY INTO DARKNESS, by John Douglas and Mark Olshaker.
(Drew/Scribner, $25.) A former F.B.I. profiler describes the nature of vicious serial
criminals.
